ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: The course provided an opportunity to engage with recently published texts exploring questions of relation to land and animal that were new to me.

I was introduced to texts both within and outside the discipline that I might not have come across without taking the course. I was challenged to think about the relationship of doctrine to body, land, and animal within and beyond Christianity. I developed new insight into problems of race, place, and animal welfare.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I appreciated working through much of the material to see what directions have been taken around questions of land and animal in religious studies and theology. I would have loved to read more extensively from Katherine McKittrick's Demonic Grounds, Rashad Shabazz's Spatializing Blackness, and Vandana Shiva's works. Given the way that indigenous thinking and theologizng about land was a central motivation of many of the courses questions, I also think including some indigenous thinkers or theologians would be productive.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: This is a required doctoral seminar for students in the theology subfield.
